abstract.p: Geico, US's fifth-largest auto insurer begins selling policies in New Jersey after absence of nearly 30 years after state acts to accelerate approval of rate changes and to stop requiring insurers to cover all drivers (S)

block.p: Geico, the nation's fifth-largest automobile insurer, sold policies in New Jersey last week after an absence of nearly 30 years. The company said that it decided to return after the state acted in June 2003 to accelerate approval of rate changes and to stop requiring insurers to cover all drivers. Since the changes were adopted, more than 1.5 million policyholders have received over $160 million in rate reductions and special dividends, said Holly C. Bakke, the state banking and insurance commissioner. In addition, State Farm has stopped dropping coverage for nearly 4,000 New Jersey drivers a month.

Geico, the nation's fifth-largest automobile insurer, sold policies in New Jersey last week after an absence of nearly 30 years. The company said that it decided to return after the state acted in June 2003 to accelerate approval of rate changes and to stop requiring insurers to cover all drivers. Bakke, the state banking and insurance commissioner. In addition, State Farm has stopped dropping coverage for nearly 4,000 New Jersey drivers a month.
